title: Advancing Risk Gene Discovery Across the Allele Frequency Spectrum
summary: This review paper addresses the challenge of stalled genetic risk factor discovery, particularly highlighting the 'missing middle' of variants with intermediate allele frequencies and effect sizes that are poorly captured by current methods. It systematically organizes existing strategies by variant frequency and proposes innovative approaches, including advanced variant annotation, joint modeling, phenotype refinement, and network-based inference, to enhance discovery in this critical underserved range. The ultimate goal is to provide a conceptual framework for comprehensive risk gene identification across the entire allele frequency spectrum.

title: Dynamic causal discovery in Alzheimer's disease through latent pseudotime modelling
summary: This paper introduces a novel framework for dynamic causal discovery in Alzheimer's disease (AD) by inferring a latent disease pseudotime, which orders patients along a data-driven disease trajectory independent of chronological age. It overcomes limitations of static causal models by demonstrating how causal relationships evolve over this pseudotime, significantly improving diagnostic prediction compared to age, and revealing dynamic interactions among both novel and established AD biomarkers.

title: Reproduction Numbers R_0, R_t for COVID-19 Infections with Gaussian Distribution of Generation Times, and of Serial Intervals including Presymptomatic Transmission
summary: This paper addresses a methodological discrepancy in calculating COVID-19 reproduction numbers (R_0, R_t) using the Lotka-Euler equation when considering Gaussian-distributed serial intervals (SIs) that account for presymptomatic transmission. It highlights that allowing SIs to extend to minus infinity in Lotka-Euler leads to lower R values than predicted by the discretized renewal equation. The main contribution is a reformulated Lotka-Euler equation that incorporates an explicit lower cut-off for Gaussian SI distributions, enabling more consistent and accurate estimation of reproduction numbers in the context of presymptomatic transmission.

title: Integrating Temporal and Structural Context in Graph Transformers for Relational Deep Learning
summary: This paper introduces the Relational Graph Perceiver (RGP), a novel graph transformer architecture designed for relational deep learning. RGP addresses limitations of existing models by integrating both long-range temporal and structural contexts via a unique temporal subgraph sampler and a cross-attention-based latent bottleneck. The model achieves state-of-the-art performance across various benchmarks while supporting joint learning for diverse predictive tasks, offering a general and scalable solution for complex dynamic relational data.

title: Learning from Single Timestamps: Complexity Estimation in Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy
summary: STC-Net is a novel AI framework that automates surgical complexity estimation in Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy using the Parkland Grading Scale (PGS) directly from full surgical videos. It employs weak temporal supervision to jointly localize and grade inflammation severity, achieving over 62% accuracy and F1-score and outperforming non-localized baselines by over 10% on a large dataset. This approach offers a scalable solution for post-operative analysis and surgical training.

title: $μ$NeuFMT: Optical-Property-Adaptive Fluorescence Molecular Tomography via Implicit Neural Representation
summary:
Fluorescence Molecular Tomography (FMT) is a promising technique for
non-invasive 3D visualization of fluorescent probes, but its reconstruction
remains challenging due to the inherent ill-posedness and reliance on
inaccurate or often-unknown tissue optical properties. While deep learning
methods ha...

title: Modeling Clinical Uncertainty in Radiology Reports: from Explicit Uncertainty Markers to Implicit Reasoning Pathways
summary: This paper introduces a novel framework to model and quantify clinical uncertainty in radiology reports, categorizing it into explicit (hedging phrases) and implicit (omitted reasoning) types. It leverages a combination of expert validation, large language models (LLMs), and expert-defined diagnostic pathways to address these challenges, resulting in the creation of Lunguage++, an uncertainty-aware benchmark for structured radiology reports. This resource aims to improve automated analysis, image classification, and diagnostic reasoning by incorporating a nuanced understanding of uncertainty.

title: Probabilistic Textual Time Series Depression Detection
summary: PTTSD is a novel probabilistic framework designed for detecting depression severity from utterance-level clinical interviews by predicting PHQ-8 scores. It significantly improves upon existing models by explicitly modeling uncertainty over time, offering state-of-the-art performance among text-only systems and providing well-calibrated, interpretable, and clinically relevant uncertainty-aware forecasts for decision support.

title: TRAECR: A Tool for Preprocessing Positron Emission Tomography Imaging for Statistical Modeling
summary: This paper introduces TRAECR (Template registration, MRI-PET co-Registration, Anatomical brain Extraction and COMBAT/RAVEL harmonization), a novel preprocessing and visualization tool for Positron Emission Tomography (PET) imaging data. TRAECR is designed to facilitate robust data preparation for statistical modeling, which is crucial for answering complex scientific questions in fields like Alzheimer's disease (AD) and cancer research.

title: Submanifold Sparse Convolutional Networks for Automated 3D Segmentation of Kidneys and Kidney Tumours in Computed Tomography
summary: This paper introduces a novel methodology using two-stage voxel sparsification combined with Submanifold Sparse Convolutional Networks for automated 3D segmentation of kidneys and kidney tumors in Computed Tomography (CT) scans. The approach enables high-resolution input processing with a native 3D architecture, achieving state-of-the-art accuracies competitive with KiTS23 challenge winners while significantly reducing computational resources.

title: LUME-DBN: Full Bayesian Learning of DBNs from Incomplete data in Intensive Care
summary: This paper introduces LUME-DBN, a novel full Bayesian framework utilizing Gibbs sampling to learn Dynamic Bayesian Networks (DBNs) effectively from incomplete longitudinal clinical data. It addresses the critical gap in existing methods by properly accounting for the temporal nature of missing values, which is essential for quantifying uncertainty over time. Evaluated on simulated and real-world intensive care data, LUME-DBN demonstrates superior reconstruction accuracy and convergence compared to model-agnostic imputation techniques like MICE, providing more reliable imputations and supporting informed clinical decision-making.

title: RxSafeBench: Identifying Medication Safety Issues of Large Language Models in Simulated Consultation
summary: This paper introduces RxSafeBench, a novel benchmark and framework for systematically evaluating the medication safety capabilities of Large Language Models (LLMs) in simulated clinical consultations. It addresses the lack of real-world data and evaluation in realistic settings by creating a dedicated medication safety database (RxRisk DB) and generating high-quality consultation scenarios. The study reveals that current LLMs struggle significantly with integrating contraindication and drug interaction knowledge, particularly when risks are implicitly stated, underscoring critical safety concerns for AI-driven clinical decision support.

title: Vector Traits Shape Disease Persistence: A Predator Prey Approach to Dengue
summary: This study employs a predator-prey mathematical framework to model the interactions between *Aedes* vectors and dengue pathogens, demonstrating how vector competence (vc) is a primary determinant of within-vector infection dynamics and endemic disease persistence. It reveals a fundamental biological trade-off in tropical/subtropical environments where high vector competence cannot be offset by enhanced innate immune capacity, leading to inherent instability in dengue transmission dynamics.

title: MedSapiens: Taking a Pose to Rethink Medical Imaging Landmark Detection
summary: This paper introduces MedSapiens, a novel adaptation of the human-centric foundation model Sapiens, for anatomical landmark detection in medical imaging. By leveraging multi-dataset pretraining, MedSapiens establishes a new state of the art, demonstrating that models inherently optimized for spatial pose localization provide strong, previously untapped priors for medical landmark tasks. The model achieves significant performance improvements over existing generalist and specialist methods, even in limited-data settings.

title: Covariance Descriptors Meet General Vision Encoders: Riemannian Deep Learning for Medical Image Classification
summary: This paper investigates the efficacy of covariance descriptors, which capture second-order statistics, for medical image classification, particularly focusing on their integration with deep learning through SPDNet. The authors propose constructing these descriptors from features extracted by powerful pre-trained General Vision Encoders (GVEs) like DINOv2 and MedSAM. Their findings demonstrate that GVE-derived features consistently outperform handcrafted features, with SPDNet leveraging DINOv2 features achieving superior performance compared to state-of-the-art methods on the MedMNSIT benchmark.

title: Protein aggregation in Huntington's disease
summary: This paper highlights that protein aggregation due to expanded polyglutamine in huntingtin is a likely cause of neuronal death in Huntington's disease. It proposes two main aggregation mechanisms – hydrogen bonding (polar-zipper) and covalent cross-linking (transglutaminase) – noting that while cell culture models show predominant hydrogen bonding, the nature of these stabilizing bonds in patient brains remains unknown, critically influencing therapeutic strategies.

title: Systematic Evaluation of Preprocessing Techniques for Accurate Image Registration in Digital Pathology
summary: This study systematically evaluated various preprocessing techniques, particularly color transformations, to enhance accurate image registration between hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and non-linear multimodal images in digital pathology. The research found that CycleGAN color transformation consistently achieved the lowest registration errors, significantly improving spatial alignment compared to other methods. These findings underscore the critical role of effective preprocessing in enabling reliable multi-modal image analysis for advanced applications in digital pathology.

title: Deep Learning Approach for Clinical Risk Identification Using Transformer Modeling of Heterogeneous EHR Data
summary: This study introduces a novel Transformer-based deep learning approach to model heterogeneous Electronic Health Record (EHR) data for clinical risk identification, effectively addressing challenges like irregular temporal patterns and diverse data modalities. The method integrates a learnable temporal encoding, multi-head self-attention, and a semantic-weighted pooling module to capture complex dependencies and semantic nuances. Experimental results demonstrate superior performance over existing models in key metrics, offering an efficient and reliable framework for clinical intelligent decision-making.

title: When Swin Transformer Meets KANs: An Improved Transformer Architecture for Medical Image Segmentation
summary:
Medical image segmentation is critical for accurate diagnostics and treatment
planning, but remains challenging due to complex anatomical structures and
limited annotated training data. CNN-based segmentation methods excel at local
feature extraction, but struggle with modeling long-range dependenci...

title: Improving the Performance of Radiology Report De-identification with Large-Scale Training and Benchmarking Against Cloud Vendor Methods
summary: This paper presents a transformer-based model significantly improving automated de-identification of radiology reports by leveraging large-scale, multimodal training data and introducing an AGE PHI category. The model achieves high F1 scores on institutional datasets and notably outperforms commercial cloud vendor systems, establishing a new benchmark for secure clinical text processing. This advancement enhances the ability to share and utilize sensitive patient data for research and AI development while maintaining privacy.

title: Left Atrial Segmentation with nnU-Net Using MRI
summary: This paper presents the application of the nnU-Net deep learning framework for accurate and automated segmentation of the left atrium (LA) from cardiac MRI scans. Addressing the limitations of time-consuming and observer-dependent manual delineation, the study demonstrates that the self-configuring nnU-Net model achieved a high mean Dice similarity coefficient of 93.5, significantly outperforming traditional methods and proving robust in delineating the LA body and proximal pulmonary veins.

title: Pediatric Appendicitis Detection from Ultrasound Images
summary: This study developed a deep learning model based on a fine-tuned ResNet architecture for automated detection of pediatric appendicitis from ultrasound images. Leveraging the Regensburg Pediatric Appendicitis Dataset, the model achieved high diagnostic performance with 93.44% accuracy, 91.53% precision, and 89.8% recall, demonstrating its capability to extract discriminative features despite common imaging challenges.

title: T-FIX: Text-Based Explanations with Features Interpretable to eXperts
summary: This paper introduces T-FIX, a novel benchmark designed to evaluate Large Language Model (LLM) explanations based on their alignment with domain expert reasoning, addressing a critical gap in current evaluation schemes that prioritize plausibility or internal faithfulness. T-FIX formalizes the criterion of "expert alignment" and proposes new, expert-developed metrics to measure this crucial aspect across seven knowledge-intensive domains, including medicine.

title: MedDChest: A Content-Aware Multimodal Foundational Vision Model for Thoracic Imaging
summary: MedDChest proposes a foundational Vision Transformer (ViT) model specifically optimized for thoracic imaging, addressing the domain gap prevalent when fine-tuning models pre-trained on natural images. It achieves this by pre-training from scratch on a massive, curated multimodal dataset of over 1.2 million Chest X-ray and CT images, incorporating a novel content-aware data augmentation strategy. The model empirically demonstrates significant superior performance over ImageNet-pretrained models on various downstream diagnostic tasks.

title: Towards Scalable Meta-Learning of near-optimal Interpretable Models via Synthetic Model Generations
summary: This paper introduces an efficient and scalable method for meta-learning interpretable decision trees by generating large-scale, realistic synthetic pre-training data composed of near-optimal decision trees. By pre-training a MetaTree transformer architecture with this synthetic data, the approach achieves performance comparable to using real-world data or computationally expensive optimal trees, significantly reducing computational costs and enhancing data generation flexibility. This strategy paves the way for scalable and efficient development of interpretable AI models, particularly relevant for high-stakes fields like healthcare.

title: PETRA: Pretrained Evolutionary Transformer for SARS-CoV-2 Mutation Prediction
summary: This paper introduces PETRA (Pretrained Evolutionary TRAnsformer), a novel deep learning model designed to predict future SARS-CoV-2 mutations. Unlike traditional transformer models that struggle with noisy raw viral RNA sequences, PETRA leverages evolutionary trajectories derived from phylogenetic trees, effectively mitigating noise and capturing the hierarchical structure of viral evolution. The model demonstrates significantly superior predictive performance for both nucleotide and spike amino-acid mutations compared to existing baselines, aiding in real-time variant surveillance and public health preparedness.

title: I Detect What I Don't Know: Incremental Anomaly Learning with Stochastic Weight Averaging-Gaussian for Oracle-Free Medical Imaging
summary: This paper introduces an unsupervised, oracle-free framework for incremental unknown anomaly detection in medical imaging, specifically designed to address label scarcity and high supervision costs. The method iteratively expands a trusted set of normal samples using lightweight adapter updates and dual uncertainty-gated admission, preventing drift and achieving significant performance gains across various medical imaging tasks. It offers an efficient and effective solution for real-world medical applications requiring anomaly detection without extensive labeled data.

title: Simulating the impact of perception bias on social contact surveys for infectious disease modelling
summary: This study simulates contact surveys to investigate how perception biases, specifically in estimating age and race of contacts, affect the accuracy of derived contact patterns used in infectious disease models. It found that these biases substantially decrease accuracy, leading to a systematic underestimation of cumulative incidence among older people and non-White individuals in Susceptible-Infectious-Recovered (SIR) models.

title: Improving Diagnostic Performance on Small and Imbalanced Datasets Using Class-Based Input Image Composition
summary: This paper introduces Class-Based Image Composition (CoImg), a novel deep learning approach that fuses multiple images of the same diagnostic class into composite visual inputs to enhance intra-class variance and information density. Applied to an imbalanced Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) retinal dataset, this method significantly improved diagnostic performance. By creating a balanced dataset (Co-OCTDL) where each sample is a 3x1 composite image, the authors achieved near-perfect accuracy (99.6%) and substantially lower false prediction rates compared to a baseline model trained on raw data.

title: Shape Deformation Networks for Automated Aortic Valve Finite Element Meshing from 3D CT Images
summary: This paper introduces a deep learning-based template-fitting pipeline for automated generation of high-quality, structured quadrilateral meshes of aortic valves from 3D CT images. The method addresses limitations of traditional approaches by ensuring uniform mesh topology and consistent correspondence across patients, simplifying network training, and improving mesh smoothness and element quality.

title: CAR T Cells from Code to Clinic: Framing Modeling Approaches with Current Translational Research Goals
summary: This paper advocates for mathematical modeling as a critical framework to overcome major translational bottlenecks in CAR T cell therapy, such as lack of persistence, toxicity, and antigen-negative relapse. It frames current and emerging modeling methodologies within therapeutic challenges, highlighting their strengths, limitations, and data gaps to enable the design of safer and more effective therapies. The authors emphasize advanced techniques like multiscale modeling and data-driven approaches, also pointing towards future modeling frontiers in other engineered immune cells.

title: Noise Injection: Improving Out-of-Distribution Generalization for Limited Size Datasets
summary: This paper addresses the critical issue of deep learning models failing to generalize to out-of-distribution (OOD) medical imaging data, particularly in COVID-19 detection from Chest X-rays (CXRs), due to learning source-specific shortcuts. The authors propose using fundamental noise injection techniques (Gaussian, Speckle, Poisson, and Salt and Pepper) during training to enhance model robustness. Their empirical results demonstrate that this method significantly reduces the performance gap between in-distribution and OOD evaluation from 0.10-0.20 to 0.01-0.06 across key metrics, improving the reliability of medical AI.

title: Higher-Order Causal Structure Learning with Additive Models
summary: This paper extends the Causal Additive Model (CAM) to incorporate higher-order interactions in causal structure learning, representing these complex relationships using directed acyclic hypergraphs (hyper DAGs). It introduces the theoretical framework, identifiability results for these novel structures, and an extended greedy CAM algorithm, demonstrating that learning such complex structures can lead to improved empirical performance in synthetic experiments.

title: FusionDP: Foundation Model-Assisted Differentially Private Learning for Partially Sensitive Features
summary: FusionDP addresses the critical challenge of preserving patient privacy while maintaining model utility when only a subset of features is sensitive. This two-step framework leverages large foundation models to impute sensitive features, then employs a modified differentially private stochastic gradient descent (DP-SGD) algorithm to train models on both original and imputed features, rigorously protecting the privacy of the original sensitive features. Evaluated on medical tasks like sepsis prediction and clinical note classification, FusionDP significantly enhances model performance compared to privacy-preserving baselines while maintaining strong feature-level privacy guarantees.

title: Climbing the label tree: Hierarchy-preserving contrastive learning for medical imaging
summary: This paper introduces a novel hierarchy-preserving contrastive learning framework designed for medical imaging, which explicitly integrates label taxonomies into self-supervised training. It leverages Hierarchy-Weighted Contrastive (HWC) and Level-Aware Margin (LAM) objectives to foster within-parent coherence and inter-level group separation, respectively. The approach consistently improves representation quality and taxonomy faithfulness over strong baselines across various benchmarks, including breast histopathology, advancing both performance and interpretability.

title: Colorectal Cancer Histopathological Grading using Multi-Scale Federated Learning
summary: This paper introduces a privacy-preserving federated learning framework for automated colorectal cancer (CRC) histopathological grading, overcoming challenges like inter-observer variability and data privacy constraints. By integrating multi-scale feature learning with a dual-stream deep learning architecture, the system achieves high accuracy, particularly for aggressive Grade III tumors, and outperforms comparable centralized models.

title: Impact of Resistance Development Mechanisms on Antibiotic Treatment Outcomes
summary: This study uses periodic ordinary differential equation (ODE) models to investigate how different antibiotic resistance mechanisms (plasmid-mediated vs. mutation-driven) influence antibiotic treatment outcomes, specifically regarding infection clearance and inhibiting further resistance. The findings suggest that fixed dosing schedules are more effective against plasmid-mediated resistance, while mutation-driven resistance tends to select for fully resistant strains upon treatment failure. Additionally, a twice-daily regimen consistently outperforms a once-daily regimen for infection clearance, and a 'catch-up' strategy is superior for missed doses of short half-life antibiotics.

title: Whisper Leak: a side-channel attack on Large Language Models
summary: The paper introduces "Whisper Leak," a novel side-channel attack that infers user prompt topics from encrypted Large Language Model (LLM) traffic by analyzing packet size and timing patterns. Despite TLS encryption, this metadata leakage allows for highly accurate topic classification across 28 popular LLMs, posing significant privacy risks for users in sensitive domains like healthcare. While some mitigation strategies were evaluated, none offered complete protection against this industry-wide vulnerability.

title: Final state sensitivity and fractal basin boundaries from coupled Chialvo neurons
summary: This paper investigates the dynamics of two asymmetrically coupled Chialvo neurons, revealing multistability with distinct chaotic and nonchaotic attractors. It demonstrates that despite individual non-chaoticity, the coupled system's state space is dominated by a chaotic basin, separated by a fractal boundary that leads to extreme final state sensitivity, with significant implications for biological neuron synchronization and neurological disease understanding.

title: SHIELD: Securing Healthcare IoT with Efficient Machine Learning Techniques for Anomaly Detection
summary: This study proposes SHIELD, a machine learning-driven framework designed to enhance healthcare IoT security by effectively detecting both malicious cyberattacks and faulty device anomalies. Evaluating eight diverse ML models on a 200,000-record dataset, the research identified XGBoost as achieving 99% accuracy for anomaly detection, while K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) demonstrated near-perfect performance for attack detection with minimal computational overhead. These findings significantly improve early threat detection, aiming to prevent data breaches and ensure safe medical device operations.

title: ChiMDQA: Towards Comprehensive Chinese Document QA with Fine-grained Evaluation
summary: This paper introduces ChiMDQA, a novel Chinese Multi-Document Question Answering Dataset designed to meet the growing demand for high-quality NLP resources in various domains, including medical treatment. It comprises 6,068 rigorously curated QA pairs from long-form documents across six distinct fields, categorized into ten fine-grained types, serving as a robust foundation for document comprehension, knowledge extraction, and intelligent QA system development.

title: Current validation practice undermines surgical AI development
summary: This paper identifies and categorizes widespread validation pitfalls in AI-based surgical video analysis that hinder clinical adoption. Through a multi-stage Delphi process with international experts, a comprehensive catalog of these pitfalls was developed, covering data, metrics, and reporting. The authors provide empirical evidence that current practices, which often neglect temporal and hierarchical data structures, lead to misleading results and undermine the reliability of surgical AI.

title: Tensor-Efficient High-Dimensional Q-learning
summary: This paper introduces Tensor-Efficient Q-Learning (TEQL), a novel reinforcement learning algorithm designed to address the challenges of high-dimensional state-action spaces, particularly the curse of dimensionality, in Q-learning. TEQL enhances low-rank tensor decomposition with improved block coordinate descent, incorporating unique exploration strategies and regularization mechanisms. It achieves superior sample efficiency and total rewards compared to conventional matrix-based and deep RL methods, making it suitable for resource-constrained applications like healthcare.

title: Phenotype discovery of traumatic brain injury segmentations from heterogeneous multi-site data
summary: This paper addresses the significant heterogeneity of Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) by analyzing T1-weighted MRI data from the large-scale, multi-site FITBIR repository. Through a rigorous methodological pipeline including data harmonization, segmentation of 132 brain regions, and statistical analysis, the study identified significant volumetric differences in 37 ROIs between TBI patients and controls. Critically, these differences clustered into three distinct injury patterns (phenotypes) affecting specific brain regions, providing a data-driven approach to characterize TBI's structural impact.

title: NAP: Attention-Based Late Fusion for Automatic Sleep Staging
summary: This paper introduces NAP (Neural Aggregator of Predictions), an attention-based late fusion model designed to overcome the heterogeneity of polysomnography (PSG) signals for automated sleep staging. NAP adaptively combines predictions from multiple frozen, pretrained single-channel models using a novel tri-axial attention mechanism, achieving state-of-the-art zero-shot generalization across diverse datasets and outperforming individual predictors and simple ensembles.
